This #BankingOnValues Day, the @Global Alliance for Banking on Values (GABV) is making us rethink what banking can truly be when guided by values.   In a world where AI shapes our perceptions‚Äîespecially in banking‚Äîit's often focused on products, profits, and quarterly earnings. But what about the deeper narrative?   Let's uncover the inspiring story of values-based banking, where finance isn't just about numbers but is dedicated to serving people, the planet, and a greater purpose. post_caption: Recently I had a really bad experience with **City Bank** and I feel it needs to be said.  They came to us first and encouraged us to take a loan. From day one, we were very clear: **we only need the loan if a specific amount can be approved at a low interest rate. Otherwise, we are not interested.**   They assured us that they have a **manufacturing loan scheme with low interest** and clearly said that **we are eligible**.  Based on that assurance, they asked for everything ‚Äî full sales data, internal financials, trade licenses of all branches, stock lists, factory licenses, and many other documents. Not only that, they also asked for **my parents‚Äô NID and signatures**, plus a **third-party guarantor**. We arranged all of it. Everyone was physically present at the bank, signed their papers, and even gave **fingerprint verification**.  Then after **five days**, they came back and said they could offer **only 30% of the loan amount** we originally discussed.  My simple question is ‚Äî **if they were not sure, why take signatures and fingerprints from my parents and the guarantor in the first place?** Wasn‚Äôt all the sales data and financial information enough for them to decide before involving guarantors? Why collect sensitive personal information and signatures when the actual loan amount was never confirmed?  This process wasted our time and unnecessarily involved family members and a third party, all based on promises that were not honored. Honestly, this doesn‚Äôt feel professional, and it definitely doesn‚Äôt feel ethical.  Just sharing my experience so others can be aware.
